Q1.qn_txt: The ratio of manufacturing cost of item A and item B is 3:5. The manufacturer sets the printed selling price of both the items 30% higher than their respective manufacturing cost. If the Seller gives 10% off on the printed prices and makes a profit of \$40.8 by selling both the items, what is the difference in manufacturing cost of item A and item B?

options.6: I do not understand this question

Q1.1.qn_txt: If the Printed price of an item is 30% more than its production cost, and the selling price of the item is 10% less than the printed price, how much profit did the seller make over the printed price?

options.6: I do not understand this question

Q1.1.1.qn_txt: If the production cost of an item is \$100 and the printed selling price of the item is 30% more than the production cose, what is the printed selling price?

Q1.1.2.qn_txt: If the Printed price of an item is \$130 and the seller sells the item at 10% less than the printed price, what is the selling price of the item?

Q1.2.qn_txt: If 17% of some amount is \$40.8, what is the total amount?

options.6: I do not understand this question

Q1.3.qn_txt: If the ratio of cost of item A to the cost of item B is 3:5 and the total cost of the two item is \$240 then what is the cost of item A and item B respectively?

options.2: I do not understand this question

Q1.3.1.qn_txt: If the ratio of production cost of item A to that of item B is 3:5, what portion of the total production cost is the production cost of item A?

options.6: I do not understand this question

Con1: Let us, for the time being, treat the two items together as a single item. Let the production cost of the item be \$100.
Con2: The production cost of the item is \$100.
S1.1.1: Now, the printed price is 30% more than the production cost. Therefore, the printed price is $$\$(100+100\times30\%)=\$130$$
S1.1.2: The selling price is 10% less than the printed price. Now, 10% of \$130 is \$13. Therefore the selling price is $$\$130-\$13=\$117.$$
Con3:
The production cost of the item is \$100 and the selling price is \$117. Hence seller made \$17 profit.
Now \$17 profit on \$100 production cost means the seller made 17% profit.
S1.2:
17% of some amount is \$40.8.
1% of the amount is $\$\frac{40.8}{17}$
the whole amount (i.e. 100%) is $$\$\frac{40.8}{17}\times100=\$2.4\times100=\$240 $$
Con4: Therefore, The total production cost of the two items is \$240. Now,
S1.3.1: The ratio of production cost of item A and item B is 3:5. Let the cost of Item A is \$$3x$. Then the cost of item B is \$$5x$. Total cost is \$$(3x+5x)=\$8x$. Hence, the production cost of item A is $\frac{3x}{8x}=\frac{3}{8}$th portion of the total cost.
